commentBody: I particularly enjoy reading constructor notes that share stories of success after much persistence. Congratulations, Chad, on a solid and very likeable debut.

Natick focal point today will be 7D and 18A.  I guessed right, but the two proper names seem fairly obscure and uninferable to me.  The astronaut was not one of the most famous; certainly Sally Ride and Christa MacAuliffe, the teacher who perished in the Challanger disaster, are better known.  And the indigenous Canadian would be an outright guess for practically everyone south of the St. Lawrence Seaway.  And maybe for many north of it.

I guessed N correctly, but it could have just as easily been Y.  Or even J.

I can see people having a fit over this crossing, and I wouldn't blame them.

I give this puzzle a THUMBSUP!

Get it? THELIKESOFYOU?

I'll see myself out.
Before I was married, I too frequently ordered NOON IONS on lunch dates. NOON anIONS only if the date were a GORGEous SECRET CRUSH.
I‚Äôm thoroughly charmed with this puzzle and your constructor notes, Chad. Please Ms. Ringwald, made Chad‚Äôs request come true.
Congrats on the puzzle! I enjoyed it.

A fine thing, I'm smitten by the properly Wednesdayness of this, its joie d'esprit and adept intelligent friendliness, but does anyone say "page bookmarks"? Bookmarks. Page markers. But not page bookmarks. 

I was out in Easthampton visiting friends once, maybe 15 years ago, and it turned out that Thomas Harris and his wife lived next door (the author of "Silence of the Lambs" from whence that line about fava beans comes). My pal took me over and introduced me to Mrs. Harris, Thomas being away. It was cool. In her sitting room there was a hockey goalie's mask on the wall. Then I realized it was the mask that Anthony Hopkins wore in that movie when he was taken out of his cage! "Would you like to try it on?" Mrs. Harris said, behind me. I felt a chilly tingling creeping up my spine and didn't say anything. "Would you like a glass of chianti? I have some right here."

Loved this puzzle. Nice debut. I agree Anna crossing innu is a bit of a Natick. Had NO GARLIC before NO ONION, but a four letter Atari related movie ending in OA, but TRON did work so onion went in place of garlic. Personally I happen to hate raw onions and love Italian food so don‚Äôt mind garlic food on a first date. I do mind someone my age still living with parents and still‚Ä¶ ok, I will stop grumping about my last first date

I always feel safe when I see Jeff Chen‚Äôs name on a byline, and today was no exception. This was a pretty fun solve, and actually even a bit of a challenge for a Wednesday, I definitely had to jump around a bit before getting a firm foothold. The ANNA/INNU Natick didn‚Äôt bother me; I wonder if any of our foreign friends who don‚Äôt like brands (not naming any names) will get put off with ASICS on top of PABST. And anyone who doesn‚Äôt know MEEMAW never saw ‚ÄúBig Band Theory‚Äùor ‚ÄúYoung Sheldon‚Äù.

I thought this was a charming theme and I love turns of phrases that can be twisted like this, even if it is something that people say in movies but not in real life, in my experience. Fresh theme entries and some great additional clues‚ÄîGORGE, HAIRSTYLES, BUNGEE, notably.

Congrats Chad and I‚Äôm thrilled you stuck with it. I thought I may have had the record with upwards of 30 rejections before I got published‚Äîsome of us don‚Äôt mind hitting our heads against the wall, apparently, or at least enjoy creating puzzles so much we don‚Äôt mind if they never see the light of day. Keep them coming!

Mostly enjoyable with an unnecessarily vague NE corner; IMP / UMPS / QUIRK / GUMMO and NIPPY did not fall into place as easily as the rest of the puzzle.

I tried variations of NASTY / OUTS / GUIDO / ILOSE / IFOLD / IMOUT ‚Ä¶ due largely to the firm belief that JACKANAPES implied something plural, which surprised me when IMP worked.

Anyway good puzzle overall, cheers.

OK, there's one bit of crossword hoariness that's been irritating me for quite a while, so on the occasion of 48A, I will note that there is a frankly obnoxious bias built into this trite clue-answer pair, which is that you don't know if someone studying English actually knows more languages than you do in the first place.

I have been a technical editor who specialized in prose from non-native speakers. "EFL," for "English as a foreign language," serves quite accurately. And it's nobody's business what time of day someone might have available for such training.
I was entertained.

I‚Äôm seeing some comments that make it sound like this one was tricky for many?

I had the opposite experience. Flew through this in less than half my average time while watching old Crocodile Hunter reruns. Nearly a PB. 

Leave to Steve Irwin to get the brain firing. Fun puzzle!

What a delightful gem of a puzzle. It brought a smile to my face, making this November day as sunny and warm as in the middle of spring. The joy the wonderful constructors and the unfailingly masterful editors so graciously allowed me and all of us to experience was beyond anything I have ever thought possible. I believed I loved my wife, my father, my dog. But no! I knew nothing of love. This puzzle showed me how insignificant all I had felt before had been. This, *this* is what true love feels like! I am so blessed to be alive and thus have the privilege of filling grids such as this - so full of effervescent wit, so fresh, so utterly cheerful.

A thousand thanks. Nay! A million, and a kiss üòò

Not bad at all once I found my footing! Seemed a tad daunting out of the gate, but once again some 30 odd years of American media exposure has left me with a somewhat valuable deposit of ASSETS for these puzzles.

Definitely got caught on NOONIONS for a moment, the much more vampiric NOGARLIC was my go-to, but fortunately TRON got me back into the grid. I also experimented with the STOICS being important teachers to those in certain lines of work - I suppose in these ever rampant capitalist times I don‚Äôt often feel like I see businessmen and ETHICS in the same sentence‚Ä¶ 

Happy to say I never said IQUIT. And I‚Äôm sure you are too, Chad. Great debut in the eyes of this relative NYT newbie.

Some really fun clues made for a most delightful solve.  I enjoyed all of this puzzle, especially DOPPELGANGER, which was one of my first fills. My husband has one in Munich. A friend told us that when he was traveling in Germany, he "saw my husband" on the street one day and rushed up to him, grabbed his arm and said, "Why didn't you tell me you were going to be here!!"  A withering look from "my husband" as he firmly removed our friend's hand from his arm, said something in German, and turned away.  Our friend thought he must be hallucinating, because the double continued to look so exactly like my husband, even when he spoke.

Folklore says we all have one somewhere.  Do I?
Very close to the Platonic form of a Wednesday NY Times crossword, in this ingenu's opinion.

For most of my lifetime, the $10 Canadian banknote has had a purple hue.  When Queen Elizabeth II ascended the throne in 1952 on the death of her father, King George VI, the banknotes were re-designed to show her likeness on all of our paper currency.  It wasn‚Äôt until 1969 that portraits of past Canadian Prime Ministers began to replace the Queen on all but the $20 bill.  

John A. MacDonald graced the $10 bill until his image was replaced by that of Viola Desmond in 2018.  She was our version of Rosa Parks; a symbol of the fight against racial discrimination.  In 1946, she challenged racial segregation at a cinema in New Glasgow, Nova Scotia, by refusing to leave a whites-only area of the Roseland Theatre. For this, she was convicted of a minor tax violation for the one-cent tax difference between the seat that she had paid for and the seat that she used, which was more expensive.

I enjoyed this one very much. It felt breezy (except for GUMMO, who was totally unfamiliar to me), but not so easy that I didn‚Äôt have to work for it. 

My personal preference is for entries/cluing that are challenging enough to require multiple passes, but which I can solve by thinking or remembering and not looking up, and that was this puzzle for me today. 

I‚Äôve had 2.5 years of fun with the Mini, and just passed my 6-month mark of solving the full NYT crosswords (and nearly that same amount of time perusing these daily columns and comments). I think I‚Äôm hooked!

Here's an odd one: every so often one of my clues appears in French. I figure it's looking for the French translation but when I get stumped & look at another clue, it's in French, too. The whole puzzle is suddenly in French, but only the clues. The answers are still in English. When I refresh the screen, the questions return to English.

What's odd is that French is my second language so at first it all looks kind of normal. What am I doing to trigger this?

Congratulations on the debut, Chad. Persistence pays off! And I really liked your constructor notes, so I tried to do my part to help you out‚Ä¶ https://www.instagram.com/p/DQqiNZzFZFpL2IVWzRwAmdZ8neRqjmsg395uik0/?igsh=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ== Hoping Molly Ringwald makes your wish come true.
Just to be picky, the Marx brothers had nicknames that they used on stage and in the case of Gummo who rarely went on stage and managed the other brothers, his was a nickname and not a stage name
I enjoyed this puzzle but can someone explain 14A - I googled the meaning of scad and it apparently stands for spontaneous coronary artery disease - how do you get from this to alot?

Gummo is to the Marx Brothers what Peyton Randolph* is to the Founding Fathers.

Tricky clue!

*I‚Äôm sure someone will tell me I‚Äôve got this wrong! Apologies in advance!
Re yesterday and KELSO - a small town in the Scottish Borders, maybe the original? Visit the River Tweed Salmon Fishing Museum.

New-ish solver struggled in the top right corner mainly because the only Marx brother I know is Harpo but also because I was working on 12D (Jackanapes) my understanding is that if the clue is plural the answer must match it. Can someone explain why this is IMP and not IMPS?
Thank/s
Felt like I was struggling but finished with no mistakes  beating my average time üò≥üòú

Nice play on the phrase THE LIKES OF YOU. Great fill too, especially DOPPELGANGERS, SECRET CRUSHES, GORGE and IGNEOUS. I'm glad you kept trying, Chad. Lynn Morris with THE LIKES OF YOU: https://youtu.be/Rv30IB50uFI?si=LZF41Wye7ThPH4nw
Some dos, which need not be mentioned here, are also don'ts. Enjoyable puzzle!

Although health care is probably the first place I would like us to emulate Canada, I enjoyed thinking through 40A.

I knew it couldn't be ONE, because I was aware that years ago Canada had taken the necessary step to popular acceptance of their dollar coin: elimination of the unit note. Thus, I quickly filled in TWO, and then I realized they had probably done the same thing when the introduced the Toonie, which got me to TEN. Of course, aside from realizing that they're different colors, I have no idea what color Canadian bills are.

Cash has become increasingly irrelevant, but I still enjoy getting dollar coins (typically in rest area vending machines), and I wish we would eliminate the dollar bill so that people might finally start using what I still call a silver dollar.

Good challenge for a Wednesday.  And thanks once again to Jeff Chen for his contributions to crossword culture.

I love the irony of having the answer IQUIT in this puzzle, right up at the top even.  Here is a constructor whose submissions were rejected more than 40 times ‚Äì 40 times! -- AND HE CONTINUED TO SUBMIT!

He had a dream and remained riveted to it.  He followed the path of Thomas Edison, who said, ‚ÄúI have not failed.  I‚Äôve just found 10,000 ways that won‚Äôt work‚Äù, and forged on.

Bravo, sir.  I am inspired by your example.  In addition, I loved your play on the word LIKES in this theme.  I loved seeing the symmetrical sing-song BUNGEE and MEEMAW, not to mention the long-O-tail set of ROBO, GUMMO, TRIO, EXPO, ARLO and wannabe AFROS.

A fun solve, topped by the puzzle‚Äôs inspiring backstory, and the hopeful reminder that a long, long period of bad news can have a happy ending ‚Äì well, your puzzle was a gift, Chad, along with a dollop of feel-good provided by Jeff Chen‚Äôs generosity in helping you throughout your trek.

Thank you both ‚Äì you‚Äôve made my day!

At the start I seemed to be in sync with the puzzle creators. I could do no wrong. 
Not so fast as I first thought.
Loved figuring out 38D!
I'll probably never go on a first date again, but I'll never forget the advice!

Ah, that purple mint ten majesty.

(Colourblind, so I often think it‚Äôs blue. And I don‚Äôt notice blushing. And I think ‚Äúpage bookmarks‚Äù sounds odd.)
Nice job, dude. Fun puzzle.

BUNGEE and INNU and TEE delayed my solve time because I for the life of me couldn‚Äôt figure out what BUNGEE could be. Then, duh. Can only be grateful basic cluing trucks still trip me up, otherwise what fun would this be?

Lovely puzzle!
What kind of scout wears a VEST? Sash, yes, but never saw a vest.  What am I missing??

Congratulations on your debut, Mr. Hazen!
Persistence does indeed pay off. You have produced a fine, entertaining puzzle. And you‚Äôve included every letter but the Zed! But since that‚Äôs the keystone of your surname, I giving your puzzle pangram status.
I hope Chad updates us if Molly responds. As Mike would say, that would be "classic".

Looks like the developers fixed the issue where one used to zoom to the top of the main thread when backing up from a comment thread. Now it's just buttery smooth right back to where you left off from. 

Well done üíªüíªüíª team!  I see you.
I loved this puzzle and the theme! A great debut, Chad. I had a few wrong answers but was able to figure them out easily enough. A great start to my Wednesday. Y‚Äôall have a good one!

That theme answer may be tough for many. Idiomatic and old-fashioned. I don't think I've even heard my MEEMAW say that phrase.

So our constructors are JACKANAPES. üòâ

calls to mind the old joke about Macbeth in his castle secure in Act V  "Fear not till Birnam Wood  Do come to Dunsinane,‚Äù  

Of course in the end the wood does come and (in the old vaudeville version) someone runs out on stage and hollers

"CHEESE IT - THE COPSE!"

The bottom half of this puzzle was quite good, but I never quite found my footing with the rest.

The themed clues worked, I guess. I think that if you are going to force a theme, those answers should all fall in line with that theme, whereas here they are all variations. Again, it works, but I found it a pain and not enjoyable to solve for. A minor personal nit (and I‚Äôm sure people will come for me, have a cookie instead), but I found it a real drawback of this puzzle.

I‚Äôm glad the constructor was able to get their puzzle published, but I don‚Äôt look forward to more from them. 

Oh well, onto tomorrow. Have a great day!
Molly Ringwald is also an author who has done book signings in my little town. Movie 16 Candles is a classic. Thoroughly enjoyed your puzzle. More please.
Great job you guys! I don't know why but I've always liked that Have your people call my people line.

Well....congrats to Chad!  (What a relief...a bad puzzle might have led to a H*nging Chad, eh?)
But other than that, I was kind of "meh" with the puzzle until I read the column and the explanation of "THE LIKES"...

I had a HI-HAT for the "drum kit" item...but "trap set" was what the percussion guys in the band called it.  
Wanted SCOPS for 'Old poets' but I guess that was too, too old.
JFK before RFK (who is no doubt rolling in his grave).
Fave entry:  44D, for "Important course in business, law, and medical school"...not to mention politics, parenting, and Life.

Typical Wednesday workout for me. And... had to stop and ponder for a moment after I had it all filled in before I entirely grasped the theme. That was a nice touch. And... puzzle find today was from a search for DOPPELGANGERS. That only appeared in one other puzzle and it was one of five theme answers in a Tuesday puzzle from February 15, 2005 by Gene Newman. All of those answers had exactly the same clue: "Ringers." And the other same theme answers were: LOOKALIKES IDENTICALTWINS SPITTINGIMAGES DUPLICATES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/15/2005&g=35&d=A ...

Cute! And some great fill: I love the way some words sound even if not said aloud, like IGNEOUS or COPSE. 

The film references were all gimmes today; TRON (with the Pong clue) and Silence of the Lambs, plus 16 Candles: methinks Chad might be a fellow Gen-Xer? üòÅ

I loved the revealer, and the twist away from the sarcasm with which I associate it. SECRET CRUSHES, what a thrill! Like others, though, I feel PAGE with BOOKMARKS is a little too stretchy. That plus the now deprecated HTTP (as opposed to HTTPS) leads me to believe that area could have been reworked... Change the answer to the more acceptable SITE BOOKMARKS (and the clue from "site" to "web")... But it's a small nit, and I appreciate the publication, FTW! 

Very last letter was the M crossing the Marx brother with the [Jacknapes]. Held my breath a microsecond and ‚Äì phew! 

Thanks guys!

The two uses of the word 'prop' is very clever. I was relieved not to have to live another day in a capo scandal. If the banjo players come out of the woodwork to protest 'knee,' I'm cancelling my wife's overpriced games subscription.
  I don't expect an uprising between the hihats and snares, but it would be comical. The cowbell people may be offended, though.
  Thank you Deb for today's image of the twins. I'm guessing thats either a meetup of identical twins, or the girls spending time with their two PEEPAWS (or papaws).

Tougher than usual Wednesday for me, but good puzzle.  I got stuck for a while on the top left corner.  I still have no idea what a 'Scad' is.  And I tend to think of BARDS as more singers than poets (Maybe my D&D knowledge worked against me there), and I'm not sure ALOOF clue quite made sense.

THE LIKES OF YOU theme and answers were great and lots of nice figure-outables with not too many obscure proper names.
GUMMO slowed me down a little in the NE but otherwise flew through this one

I recently learned that COPSE can also be a verb, meaning to thin out a thicket so that the remaining trees will grow straighter. The context was English bowmen encouraging the growth of yew trees, from which they could later make longbows.
üëç; if you get what I‚Äôm saying. Save the NW corner, this one solved like a song. https://youtu.be/RkycBqjU2Co?si=wij2Wbs5Nh6ieTvi I THANK All, Bru

I'm glad Chad Hazen persisted!  I found today's puzzle positively perfect.

I hope to see more of Chad's puzzles.

One thing you can be sure of when a puzzle author makes his debut: they will read every single comment. So, Hi, chad! Your job, which you say you love, reminds me of the Cheers episode when Norm finally gets the gig of his dreams: beer taster at a brewery. In case you've never seen it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgouWHo4RhU
Although [38-Down], the clues were Funyuns.
Very disappointingly bland theme for a Wednesday.

I not don't done did this puzz.

Great theme!

18A seems akin to the multi-purpose "innit", innit.

"Bruv, all them onions n bits n bobs dripping down your phiz make you look a right naff spotted deck, innu."
Yuk.  PAGEBOOKMARKS??????

Awesome debut, Chad Hazen!  I'm so glad you persisted, and I hope to see more from you. You and Jeff make a great team! Thanks, also, for sharing your submission journey with us. What a fabulous example of perseverance!

Happy, happy Wednesday, everyone!
Unguessable theme and rather ho-hum predictable short fills.... Maybe this should have been another rejection.

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Mr. Hazen! Nicely done!

About halfway through last night, I got too sleepy to finish. Coming back this morning, the NE seemed to take forever to figure out because I wanted TOre or TOrn for [Snagged] and couldn‚Äôt come up with IGNEOUS until I got the O. It didn‚Äôt help that except for Groucho, all of the more famous Marx Brothers used five-letter stage names.

Congrats on the debut, Chad! 
It wasn't until the bottom of the grid that I was able to crack this one open. Loved the clues for BUNGEE, NOONIONS, and HATCH. Nicely done!

I don't know what 'C-suite degs' means, but got the solution with crossers, still no clearer. 

However, that's a minor issue for me, and the rest was fairly straightforward, without being overly easy.

Very nice.
‚Äúpage bookmarks‚Äù?
Can someone explain ‚Äúsimile‚Äôs center‚Äù to me?

Didn't find this "very likable". Solved it, but felt little excitement or interest.

PAGEBOOKMARKS seems an awfully contrived thematic entry. Found the theme rather dull to boot.

DOPPELGANGERS and MEEMAW were interesting. The latter came easily since I have been re-watching episodes of "Young Sheldon" recently. Don't think I've seen INNU before.
Here is the incomparable Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau with a little Schubert: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j24i8-kx8-c&list=RDj24i8-kx8-c&start_radio=1

I hold an MBA and for many years was a partner in a small business. I was invited back to the University of San Francisco, my Alma Mater, as a guest lecturer on small business by the business school. In the course of a wide ranging discussion, I was asked to name the most important class I had taken for my degree. I immediately answered ETHICS. The hosting professor quickly validated my response and the class spent the rest of the time discussing the topic.
It‚Äôs not working on my app, is this happening to anyone else?
Why is jackanapes plural, but IMP is singular? It seems like this goes against usual conventions, but I might just be an idiot.
Terrific debut. I really enjoyed the solve. Thanks!

The two most indistinguishable celebrity doppelg√§ngers:
Will Arnet and Patrick Wilson.
Second place:
Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Javier Bardem

Solved in my average time but felt there were some questionable answers as other have listed. The NE corner was really a challenge.. Lately Wednesday puzzles have been head scratchers so I guess we are on par‚Ä¶

SECRETCRUSHES and PAGEBOOKMARKS are both things you like, while DOPPELGANGERS are things that look like you. Pretty muddled as a theme, would've worked better to come up with a third thing you like to keep and dump the doubles. Otherwise pretty straightforward fill, solved about 35% faster than my usual Wed, with some fun clues. Congrats on the debut!

Struggling with how ‚ÄúPagemarks‚Äù Is part of the theme. Isn‚Äôt it redundant to ‚ÄúSecret Crushes?‚Äù Seems a bit of a stretch to me. Otherwise really enjoyed it and thought it appropriate to a Wednesday puzzle.

Am I the only one struggling with the fact that a GORGE is not a pass? A pass divides two watersheds while a GORGE is defined by a single watershed. 

I get that the clue is kinda cute, "Deep Pass" definitely had me thinking "Hail Mary", especially in the heart of football season, but I cant abide calling a GORGE a pass.
There are two BART lines that terminate at SFO

Sorry, but "Trib" as a contraction of "Tribune" is just too rich for me. Wiktionary, which is extremely generous with its abbreviations, only lists it as a possible shortening of "tributary", alongside another unrepeatable definition which was new to me.
Count this puzzle as among the likes of me. I thought the twist on the theme was charming, and I had no trouble discerning it.
I really enjoyed this one. Challenging, but fun.
I‚Äôd only ever known Groucho, Harpo, and Zeppo. Today I learned about Chico and GUMMO.
Not crazy about PAGEBOOKMARKS, but overall cute.

Oh Chad and Jeff, this was a humdinger! 

Started out very crunchy for me - scads of white space after my first two passes. Uh-oh. And putting in STOCK CAR left me with ‚Äúkook‚Äù for Snagged, and that just didn‚Äôt make a lick of sense. But persistence still pays, and eventually things came together. 

Many things to learn today, and I love that. Thank you both!

@Steve L

Well I thought it was related to Inuit, so I guessed that as well, and AN-A had limited options (maybe a Y). So I think it was guessable but you are right, not many would know either outright.
@Steve L Not to mention knowing the ten dollar Canadian banknote is purple! I know Inuit are native people but didn‚Äôt know Innu is the singular form of Inuit.

I didn't like this crossing not because INNU is a tribe that is obscure to most people, but instead because this obscurity seemed out of place in this Wednesday puzzle all of whose other entries are strictly familiar.

@DQ

The clue requires a plural, and apparently, INNU can be used as one.

The singular of Inuit is Inuk.

Close, but no cigar.

Never even noticed the bank note question, but that's inferable, as all the crosses were gentle.

@Steve L Yes on inferring the answer to the clue about the Canadian banknote, but a million other clues could have yielded the ‚Äúten‚Äù answer. Why the purple Canadian banknote??

Just reading about the Innu Nation of Labrador. Never would have done so without this crossword, I guess.

@DQ Actually Inuk is the singular for Inuit, which also appears from time to time in the xword.  The Innu live in Labrador, and the lower north shore of the St. Lawrence in Qu√©bec.  

I think INNU is fair for a Wednesday -- but then I live a few km north of the Seaway (see comment by Steve L).

@SP

Same here.

@DQ A quiz perusal of the clues used for TEN, which has appeared 840 times, shows an amazing variety of clues. Only a few ([X], 21 times in the Modern Era; [Half a score], 12 times) have been reused extensively. I guess the reason for this particular clue is "why not?" Some of the clues used are quite clever. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Finder?w=TEN
I sussed it out, too. And I'm happy to learn new things like this. (But INNU still seems out of place in this puzzle.)

@CLM
Lame Sciece didn't post yesterday, but did post either Sunday or Monday. (How quickly I forget.)

@Vaer
Dear autocorrect, please explain to me why you didn't correct Sciece to Science, yet you manage to correct so many already correct spellings to incorrect ones.

@Lame Science
That‚Äôs great! I wonder if Francis with his chemistry background ever shared NOON IONS with his colleagues at the lunch table. I usually order them with some romA TOMatoes, or in my Vietnamese PHO TONgue soup, they really spice it up!

@SP
Quick, how many syllables in
UNIONIZATION?

If you're a normal earthling, 


5 -- yoon-yun-ai-zei-shun, AI and EI as in tAIpEI

But, if you were bitten by a science bug,

6 -- un-ai-uh-nai-zei-shun, the process of losing ions

@Vaer
Perhaps the upper case S threw off the spell checker?  Try again with lower case.

@Andrzej 
Doubtful, since I have a Samsung Galaxy phone.

@Vaer

Ah, ok. Well, I do, too, and it often does the weirdest things. Even though supposedly it takes context into account, it often changes the correct "its" to "it's", for example. It generally works quite well though.
@Sam Lyons: Okay, I get it now!

@Sam Lyons

The problem with your imitation is that the likes of ad absurdum couldn't tell a science joke if his half-life depended on it.

@Andrzej

Heh, where were you when Se√±or Gato was asking us for a little brother or sister a couple of years ago and my husband told him he‚Äôd get him a pony instead.

@weird sciece

Picking those ripe Vidalia ions, huh?
@john ezra The explainer says it‚Äôs about web pages, but still not a popular phrase for sure.
@Mick, I shoulda read the column first. Always a good idea...

@john ezra
I think the nit still stands. Even on the internet you usually just say ‚Äúbookmarks‚Äù and PAGEBOOKMARKS is a little redundant whether with real books or online.  But they needed an entry symmetrical with SECRETCRUSHES and it‚Äôs such a tight, fresh theme I don‚Äôt mind at all a bit of a stretch.

@john ezra
OMG on the mask and Chianti story!!! I found that movie terrifying, in a good way.

@Andrzej
I‚Äôm from Milwaukee, and PABST advertised as ‚ÄúThe beer that made Milwaukee famous‚Äù, so easy for me.

@SP

Did it though?ü§™

@SP

Hm. Can't say I get it. Are you surprised?

@Andrzej

Rearranging of syllables, homophonically.

The beer that made Mil Walk Eee Fame Us

The beer that made Mel Fame Eee Walk Us.

@Andrzej

p.s. If you decide to have one last beer before you die, make it something other than a Pabst.

@Andrzej
FYI it's often abbreviated to PBR; don't know how often it shows up in xworld, but put it in your back pocket.

@Bob T.

üëçüèΩ

@Michael
Interesting, and for me that corner gave me my first good foothold.

@SP

Same here! Probably because of the gimme of my favorite of the oh-so-fun Marx brothers. Delightful ü´∂
@Michael That corner was last to fall for me as well. Got stuck on a different Marx and the implied plural.

@Boris
Good point

@Steve

ELL is the person, not the course. 

NYC has been calling the subject ENL (English as a New Language) for several years now. 

The night school part of the clue shouldn‚Äôt be a problem. It doesn‚Äôt mean night school is the only place that English is taught to new learners, only that it is a common way busy people who have to work can study the language. 

That‚Äôs not an explanation about ESL. It‚Äôs an explanation about how crosswords are clued. 

I am a retired ESL teacher (it was called that most of the time I was teaching, and no one minded).

EFL is for people learning English in their country (where English is not a first language, e.g. Japan).

ESL is for students learning English where English is a first language (e.g., Japanese learning English in Chicago)

At least, that's how I learned/always understood the difference.

@Boris We have our first language, the one we learned in the cradle, la langue maternelle in French. Similar phrases exist in many other languages. All the other ones, in my opinion, are second languages. What are you going to do, rank them? By what, date or fluency? No one cares if it's the seventh language you've learned. People are interested, on the other hand, if it's your mother tongue.

And some people (gasp!) learn their mother tongue from fathers! Soooo, parental language? But what about siblings and extended family?

Can English be taught at night? Why yes it can! I'd even hazard a guess that nighttime is a common time for such lessons.

Please stop manufacturing offense where none is intended. This is a puzzle, not the United Nations.

@Steve L
I like ELL. When I was teaching, ESL was changed to EAL (Additional) to reflect the fact that many children had more than one language before learning English.

@Andrzej
Do you mean literally the same word or do you mean forms from the same root AKA cognates? English has separately derived words -- learn and teach -- while its uncle German uses "lehrn" as a root for both. Hebrew uses the root LMD in different forms as learn and as cause-to-learn = teach. So what about Polish?

@RF

For those who are wondering what you're talking about, Merriam-Webster asks:

Did you know?
William de la Pole, the Duke of Suffolk, was a well-regarded commander and statesman during the Hundred Years' War. It was during his dukedom (1448-1450), however, that England lost its possessions in northern France, and a portion of the blame was pinned on de la Pole. (So potent was the blame, in fact, that he was murdered in 1450.) The unfortunate duke lost his life and also gained a nickname: Jack Napis. The Jack part came from Jack as a term of address for one deemed socially inferior; the s on the end was a common nickname element; and the api was an allusion to something on de la Pole‚Äôs heraldic badge (a kind of personal emblem): the image of an ape‚Äôs clog‚Äîa weight that was used with a chain to restrain a monkey. Jack Napis eventually developed into jackanapes, a word that referred first to a monkey or ape less than a century after the duke had met his demise. The word‚Äôs other meanings quickly followed.

@Jack McCullough yes - not so much use for  physical cash anymore! But it's always a pleasure seeing our $10 bill. Fun facts: Zeppo hated performing and eventually left to start an engineering firm. Among other things they created a custom device to carry and release the atomic bombs dropped on Japan. They also created a wristwatch that could measure your pulse and sound an alarm if it became irregular, anticipating the fitness watch.
